📅 Day 1 Study Plan: HTML Basics

Goal for today

Understand what HTML is, learn how to write headings, paragraphs, and links, and practice them in a simple webpage.

⏰ Suggested Timeline (3–4 hours)

Step 1: Get Oriented (30 min)

  • Video: What is HTML? (freeCodeCamp) → Watch from 0:00 to 11:30 only.
    This covers what HTML is, how webpages work, and sets a beginner foundation.

  • Website (reference): MDN – Introduction to HTML → Skim the first section “What is HTML?”

✅ Your Task:
Open a plain text editor (Notepad on Windows, or VS Code if you have it). Save a new file as:

html
index.html

Type:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>My First Page</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    Hello, world!
  </body>
</html>

Then double-click the file in your folder → it should open in your browser.

Step 2: Headings & Paragraphs (45 min)

  • Video: HTML Headings & Paragraphs Tutorial (Programming with Mosh) → Watch from 0:00 to 8:20.

  • Website (reference): MDN – Headings and Paragraphs

✅ Your Task:
In your index.html file, add:

html
<h1>My First Heading</h1>
<h2>My Subheading</h2>
<p>This is my first paragraph. HTML is the structure of a web page.</p>
<p>Here’s another paragraph, just for practice.</p>

Open in your browser → see the difference in heading sizes.

Step 3: Links (45 min)

  • Video: HTML Links Tutorial (Net Ninja) → Watch the whole thing (7 min).

  • Website (reference): MDN – Links

✅ Your Task:
In your file, add:

html
<h3>Useful Links</h3>
<p>Visit <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/">MDN Web Docs</a> to learn more about HTML.</p>
<p>Watch coding tutorials on <a href="https://www.youtube.com">YouTube</a>.</p>

Refresh your browser → click the links.

Step 4: Mini Project (1 hr)

Now put it all together. Create a “My First Webpage” with:

  • A big heading (your name or title).

  • At least 2 subheadings.

  • 2–3 paragraphs (introduce yourself, your goals, etc).

  • A “Useful Links” section with 2 links.

Example skeleton:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>My First Webpage</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Welcome to My Page</h1>
    <h2>About Me</h2>
    <p>Hi! I am learning web development. This is my very first webpage.</p>

    <h2>My Goals</h2>
    <p>I want to become good at HTML, CSS, and JavaScript over the next 12 weeks.</p>

    <h3>Useful Links</h3>
    <p>Check out <a href="https://www.w3schools.com/html/">W3Schools HTML</a> for more tutorials.</p>
    <p>Visit <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/">MDN Docs</a> to read official documentation.</p>
  </body>
</html>

Step 5: Quick Review (15 min)

  • Video (Optional Recap): HTML in 15 Minutes

  • Write down what you learned today:

    1. What HTML is.

    2. What headings are (<h1>–<h6>).

    3. How to make paragraphs (<p>).

    4. How to create links (<a href="...">).

✅ End of Day 1 — You now have your first working webpage.

You said:
if ever you open a tag on vs code is it complusary to align it?
ChatGPT said:

Good question 👍

No — it’s not compulsory to align or indent tags in VS Code (or in HTML in general). The browser doesn’t care about spaces, tabs, or alignment. As long as your tags are correctly opened and closed, the code will work.

For example, this works fine:

html
<html><body><h1>Hello</h1><p>This works fine</p></body></html>

But developers indent and align code for readability — so that humans (including you) can easily see the structure.

Example (much easier to read):

html
<html>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello</h1>
    <p>This works fine</p>
  </body>
</html>

💡 Tip in VS Code:

  • You don’t need to align manually every time.

  • Just press Shift + Alt + F (Windows/Linux) or Shift + Option + F (Mac) and VS Code will auto-format your HTML code neatly.

👉 Would you like me to show you a best practice template for indentation (so you know the “standard” way developers usually align HTML)?

📅 Day 2 Study Plan: HTML Images & Lists

Goal for today

Learn how to insert images into a webpage and how to organize content using lists.

⏰ Suggested Timeline (3–4 hours)

Step 1: Images Basics (45 min)

  • Video: HTML Images Tutorial (Programming with Mosh) → Watch 0:00 – 12:00 (stop before CSS part).

  • Website (reference): MDN – <img> element

✅ Your Task:

  1. Create an images folder next to your index.html.

  2. Find any picture (your photo, a logo, or download something simple). Put it inside the folder.

  3. In your HTML file, try this:

html
<h2>My Favorite Picture</h2>
<img src="images/myphoto.jpg" alt="My Photo" width="300">

  • src → path to the image.

  • alt → text shown if the image can’t load (important for accessibility).

  • width/height → control size.

Step 2: Unordered Lists (30 min)

  • Video: HTML Lists Tutorial (Net Ninja) → Watch 0:00 – 6:30

  • Website (reference): MDN – <ul>

✅ Your Task:
Add a grocery list:

html
<h2>My Grocery List</h2>
<ul>
  <li>Bread</li>
  <li>Milk</li>
  <li>Eggs</li>
</ul>

Step 3: Ordered Lists (30 min)

  • Video: HTML Ordered Lists (Net Ninja) → Continue from 6:30 – 9:30

  • Website (reference): MDN – <ol>

✅ Your Task:
Add a “Steps to Make Tea”:

html
<h2>How to Make Tea</h2>
<ol>
  <li>Boil water</li>
  <li>Add tea leaves</li>
  <li>Pour into cup</li>
  <li>Add sugar and milk</li>
</ol>

Step 4: Mix Images & Lists (45 min)

Now combine them. Example:

html
<h2>My Favorite Foods</h2>
<ul>
  <li>
    Pizza
    <img src="images/pizza.jpg" alt="Pizza" width="150">
  </li>
  <li>
    Burger
    <img src="images/burger.jpg" alt="Burger" width="150">
  </li>
</ul>

Open in your browser → you’ll see text + images nicely together.

Step 5: Mini Project (45 min)

Create a “My Hobbies Page” with:

  • A big heading (e.g. “My Hobbies”).

  • A short paragraph introducing your hobbies.

  • An unordered list of 3 hobbies (each with a small image).

  • An ordered list of “Top 5 Movies I Love”.

Step 6: Quick Review (15 min)

  • Video Recap: HTML Lists & Images in 10 Minutes

  • Write in your notes:

    • How to add an image (<img src="..." alt="...">).

    • The difference between <ul> and <ol>.

    • <li> = list item.

✅ End of Day 2 — You’ll have a page with images, ordered lists, and unordered lists.

html

</html>

🔹 Day 3: Links & Navigation

1. Learn the Basics of Links

  • 📺 Watch: HTML Links Tutorial – Bro Code (15 mins)

  • 📖 Read: MDN – HTML <a> element

👉 Key things to focus on:

  • <a href="URL">Link Text</a>

  • Absolute vs. relative URLs

  • Opening links in new tabs (target="_blank")

  • Adding a title for tooltips

2. Practice with Simple Links

  • Make a page with:

    • A link to Google

    • A link to Day 1 file on your computer (relative link)

    • A link that opens in a new tab

    • A link that shows a tooltip on hover

3. Linking to Sections (Page Navigation)

  • 📺 Watch: HTML Anchor Links – Web Dev Simplified (10 mins)

  • 📖 Read: W3Schools – HTML Links (Bookmarks)

👉 Practice:

  • Create a long page with multiple sections (<h2> headings).

  • At the top, make a table of contents with links that scroll to each section (href="#id").

  • Add a "Back to top" link at the end of each section.

4. Special Links

  • 📺 Watch: HTML Links (tel, mailto, download) – Codehal (6 mins)

👉 Practice:

  • A link that opens an email:
    <a href="mailto:someone@example.com">Send Email</a>

  • A link that dials a phone number:
    <a href="tel:+1234567890">Call Us</a>

  • A link that downloads a file (e.g., PDF).

5. Mini Project (End of Day 3)

📂 Create a “Personal Links Page”:

  • Title at the top: “My Useful Links”

  • Section 1: Favorite Websites (Google, YouTube, etc.)

  • Section 2: Internal links (link to Day 1 & Day 2 HTML files)

  • Section 3: Page Navigation (links to jump between sections of the page)

  • Section 4: Contact Me (email, phone, and a dummy “download my resume” link)

  • Style it a little with bold, italic, or underline for link texts.

✅ End of Day 3 Goal: You should be comfortable making all types of links and structuring navigation inside a page.

📅 Day 3: Divs & Spans

Total Time: ~2.5 – 3 hours

🔹 1. Introduction to <div> and <span> (30 mins)

  • 📺 Video: HTML Div and Span Explained – Bro Code (13 mins)

  • 📖 Read: W3Schools – HTML Div and W3Schools – HTML Span

👉 Notes to focus on:

  • <div> is a block-level container (takes full width).

  • <span> is an inline container (wraps around text/inline elements).

  • Both are often used for grouping and styling.

🔹 2. Hands-on Practice with Divs (30 mins)

  • Create a new file day3.html.

  • Practice:

    1. Make 3 <div> sections (Header, Content, Footer).

    2. Add background colors so you can see the blocks.

    3. Put text inside and notice how <div> behaves like a box.

⏱️ Spend 15 mins building it.
⏱️ Spend 15 mins experimenting with colors, padding, and borders.

🔹 3. Hands-on Practice with Spans (20 mins)

  • Inside your content <div>, write a short paragraph.

  • Use <span> to:

    • Highlight a word in red.

    • Make another word bold.

    • Change one word’s background color.

⏱️ Give yourself 20 mins for this.

🔹 4. Divs + Spans Together (20 mins)

  • 📺 Video: HTML Div vs Span (Quick Explanation) – Codeacademy-like, 5 mins

  • Create a profile card:

    • Wrap the whole card in a <div> with a border.

    • Inside, have:

      • Name (big text)

      • Description (paragraph with one <span> highlighted)

      • Contact info

⏱️ 20 mins total.

🔹 5. Mini Project (45 mins)

📂 “Simple Web Page Layout” using Divs & Spans

  • A <div> for Header (page title).

  • A <div> for Navigation (just put text links for now).

  • A <div> for Main Content:

    • One paragraph with some <span> highlights.

  • A <div> for Footer with copyright.

👉 Try to make it look structured by adding background colors to each <div>.
⏱️ Spend about 45 mins.

✅ End of Day 3 Goal: You should clearly understand when to use <div> (blocks/containers) and <span> (inline highlights), and be able to create a simple layout with them.

📅 Day 5 — Build a Profile Page

Total time: ~3–4 hours
Outcome: A single index.html + styles.css profile page that displays a profile picture, name, short bio, skills list, contact links and a responsive profile card/section.

1) Watch / Read (30–40 min)

Watch one short video to see the layout being built, then skim the docs.

Videos (pick 1–2):

  • Create a Personal Profile Page with HTML | Step-by-Step (beginner tutorial) — ~12 min (approx.). YouTube

  • How To Create An Easy Profile Card Using HTML And CSS — ~8 min (approx.). Good for a compact card pattern. YouTube

  • How to Make Responsive Profile Card in HTML & CSS — ~11 min (approx.). Shows responsive/flexbox adjustments. YouTube

References (read, quick skim):

  • W3Schools “How To Create a Profile Card” (example + Try-it) — handy copyable example. w3schools.com

  • MDN CSS layout / styling basics (for flexbox/grid & responsive guidance). MDN Web Docs+1

Note: I checked these resources for availability — the durations above are approximate; open the video to see the exact length.

2) File setup (5 min)

Create a project folder and files:

arduino
profile-page/
  index.html
  styles.css
  images/
    avatar.jpg      <-- your profile picture (put any image here)

3) Step-by-step build guide (time-boxed)

Step A — Starter HTML skeleton (10 min)

Create index.html with this minimal structure (paste and save):

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1" />
  <title>My Profile</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" />
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Profile wrapper -->
  <main class="profile-page">
    <section class="profile-card" id="main-profile">
      <img src="images/avatar.jpg" alt="Your Name avatar" class="avatar">
      <h1 class="name">Your Name</h1>
      <p class="role">Web Developer in training • Passion: learning</p>

      <p class="bio">
        Hi — I’m learning web development. I like building things and solving problems.
      </p>

      <h2 class="section-title">Skills</h2>
      <ul class="skills">
        <li>HTML</li>
        <li>CSS</li>
        <li>Basic JavaScript</li>
      </ul>

      <div class="links">
        <a href="mailto:you@example.com">Email me</a>
        <a href="#" target="_blank" rel="noopener">My GitHub</a>
      </div>
    </section>
  </main>
</body>
</html>

What to check (5 min):

  • Open index.html in your browser (double-click).

  • If avatar doesn't load, confirm images/avatar.jpg path & alt text.

Step B — Add styles: layout + basic look (35 min)

Create styles.css and paste this (explain after):

css
/* styles.css - simple responsive profile card */
:root{
  --bg: #f6f8fb;
  --card: #ffffff;
  --accent: #1f6feb;
  --muted: #6b7280;
  --radius: 12px;
  --maxw: 700px;
}

*{box-sizing:border-box}
body{
  margin:0;
  font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, "Segoe UI", Roboto, "Helvetica Neue", Arial;
  background:var(--bg);
  color:#111827;
  display:flex;
  align-items:center;
  justify-content:center;
  min-height:100vh;
  padding:24px;
}

/* profile card */
.profile-card{
  background:var(--card);
  max-width:var(--maxw);
  width:100%;
  border-radius:var(--radius);
  box-shadow: 0 6px 18px rgba(17,24,39,0.08);
  padding:28px;
  text-align:center;
}

/* avatar */
.avatar{
  width:140px;
  height:140px;
  object-fit:cover;
  border-radius:50%;
  border:4px solid rgba(31,111,235,0.12);
  margin-top:-80px; /* floating look if you want to overlap a header */
  background: #eee;
}

/* name, role, bio */
.name{font-size:1.6rem;margin:12px 0 4px}
.role{color:var(--accent);font-weight:600;margin:0 0 10px}
.bio{color:var(--muted);line-height:1.5;margin:0 0 18px;padding:0 10px}

/* skills list */
.skills{
  list-style:none;
  padding:0;
  margin:0 0 16px;
  display:flex;
  gap:10px;
  justify-content:center;
  flex-wrap:wrap;
}
.skills li{
  background:#f3f4f6;
  padding:8px 12px;
  border-radius:999px;
  font-size:0.9rem;
  color:#111827;
}

/* links */
.links{
  display:flex;
  gap:12px;
  justify-content:center;
  margin-top:12px;
}
.links a{
  text-decoration:none;
  padding:8px 14px;
  border-radius:8px;
  border:1px solid rgba(17,24,39,0.06);
  font-weight:600;
  color:var(--accent);
}

/* responsive tweak: make card narrower on small screens */
@media (max-width:460px){
  .avatar{width:110px;height:110px;margin-top:-60px}
  .profile-card{padding:20px}
  .name{font-size:1.2rem}
}

What this does:

  • centers the card, gives a clean white card on a soft background, shows avatar, name, skills as pill badges.

  • includes a small media query so it looks OK on phones.

Task (10 min): Save and refresh index.html. Tweak font sizes, colors, spacing to your liking.

Step C — Improve structure & accessibility (20 min)

  • Add alt text that describes the image: alt="Portrait photo of Your Name".

  • Add id="main-profile" (we already gave it as example) — useful for linking or CSS hooks.

  • Wrap contact link mailto: and include rel="noopener" on external links.

Task: Update the HTML accordingly and refresh.

Step D — Add more sections (30–40 min)

Enhance the page with an “About” and “Experience” or “Education” section using <div> containers:

Add below the card:

html
<section class="more">
  <div class="about">
    <h2>About me</h2>
    <p>I love building small projects to practice. I’m currently learning CSS layout and flexbox.</p>
  </div>

  <div class="experience">
    <h2>Experience</h2>
    <ul>
      <li>Junior web practice projects (2025)</li>
      <li>Online coursework: HTML/CSS</li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</section>

Style with a few lines in CSS (add to styles.css):

css
.more{display:grid;grid-template-columns:1fr 1fr;gap:18px;margin-top:22px;text-align:left;padding:0 10px}
.more h2{margin:0 0 8px}
.more p, .more ul{color:var(--muted);margin:0}
@media (max-width:760px){ .more{grid-template-columns:1fr} }

Goal: Practice div/section usage, and responsive grid.

Step E — Polish + make it your own (20–30 min)

  • Replace placeholder text with your real details.

  • Add/remove skills.

  • Try different avatar images and adjust object-fit.

  • Try changing colors (swap --accent variable).

  • Optional: Add a small hover effect to links or skills.

  • Shows skills as a list of pills.

  • Looks ok on phone (shrink your browser or test on your phone).

  <p><strong>Goal:</strong> Learn HTML skeleton, headings (<code>&lt;h1&gt;</code>..), paragraphs (<code>&lt;p&gt;</code>), and links (<code>&lt;a href&gt;</code>).</p>

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8" />
  <!-- viewport makes page scale correctly on phones -->
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" />
  <title>My Profile — Day 5</title>
  <!-- link to the stylesheet -->
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" />
</head>
<body>

  <!-- Main wrapper: semantic <main> because this is the main content -->
  <main class="profile-page">

    <!-- Profile card section (use id/class so you can style it and link to it) -->
    <section id="profile-card" class="profile-card">

      <!-- avatar image: src must point to images/avatar.jpg, alt is required for accessibility -->
      <img class="avatar" src="images/avatar.jpg" alt="Portrait of Your Name">

      <!-- name and role -->
      <h1 class="name">Your Name</h1>
      <p class="role">Aspiring Web Developer</p>

      <!-- short bio paragraph -->
      <p class="bio">I build small web projects to learn HTML, CSS and JavaScript. I love turning ideas into working pages.</p>

      <!-- skills list (use <ul> because this is a list of items) -->
      <h2 class="section-title">Skills</h2>
      <ul class="skills">
        <li class="skill">HTML</li>
        <li class="skill">CSS</li>
        <li class="skill">JavaScript</li>
      </ul>

      <!-- actions: links to contact (mailto) and external profile. target="_blank" + rel for security -->
      <div class="actions">
        <a class="btn" href="mailto:you@example.com">Email me</a>
        <a class="btn btn-primary" href="#" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GitHub</a>
      </div>

    </section>

  </main>

</body>
</html>

Plain-language explanation (HTML):

  • <!DOCTYPE html>: tells browsers this is modern HTML.

  • <html lang="en">: sets language (helpful for screen readers).

  • <meta charset="utf-8">: ensures characters (letters, symbols) display correctly.

  • <meta name="viewport"...>: makes the page responsive on phones.

  • The section#profile-card groups everything for the profile; id is unique and class is reusable.

  • img uses src (path to file) and alt (text for screen readers / shown when image fails). Always include alt.

  • Use ul + li for lists (skills). Use <a href="mailto:..."> for email links.

  3. If you want a placeholder image quickly, change src to https://via.placeholder.com/180 and refresh.

Phase C — Copy-paste styles.css (full starter CSS)

Create styles.css and paste exactly this (I added comments explaining each rule):

css
/* ---------- Variables & reset ---------- */
:root{
  --bg: #f6f8fb;
  --card: #ffffff;
  --accent: #0b5cff;
  --muted: #6b7280;
  --radius: 12px;
  --maxw: 720px;
}

/* include box-sizing so padding doesn't make boxes unexpectedly bigger */
* { box-sizing: border-box; }

/* Page background and center the card */
body{
  margin: 0;
  font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, "Segoe UI", Roboto, Arial, sans-serif;
  background: var(--bg);
  color: #0b1220;
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  min-height: 100vh;    /* make card vertically centered on tall screens */
  padding: 24px;
}

/* ---------- Card container ---------- */
.profile-card{
  background: var(--card);
  width: 100%;
  max-width: var(--maxw);
  border-radius: var(--radius);
  padding: 28px;
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 8px 24px rgba(2,6,23,0.06);
  position: relative; /* allows us to absolutely position inside if needed */
}

/* ---------- Avatar ---------- */
/* width & height keep the avatar square; object-fit: cover fills without distortion */
.avatar{
  width: 140px;
  height: 140px;
  border-radius: 50%;
  object-fit: cover;
  border: 4px solid rgba(11,92,255,0.12);
  margin-top: -80px;   /* pulls the image up so it overlaps the top edge for a floating look */
  background: #eee;    /* visible while image loads or if missing */
  display: inline-block;
}

/* ---------- Text ---------- */
.name {
  margin: 12px 0 4px;
  font-size: 1.5rem;
}
.role {
  color: var(--accent);
  font-weight: 600;
  margin: 0 0 10px;
}
.bio {
  color: var(--muted);
  line-height: 1.5;
  margin: 0 0 18px;
  padding: 0 10px;
}

/* ---------- Skills list (flexbox) ---------- */
/* use flexbox so skills wrap nicely and center horizontally */
.skills {
  list-style: none;
  padding: 0;
  margin: 12px 0 18px;
  display: flex;
  gap: 10px;
  justify-content: center;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
}
.skill {
  background: #f3f4f6;
  padding: 8px 12px;
  border-radius: 999px; /* pill shape */
  font-size: 0.95rem;
}

/* ---------- Buttons / links ---------- */
.actions {
  display: flex;
  gap: 10px;
  justify-content: center;
  margin-top: 8px;
}
.btn {
  display: inline-block;
  padding: 10px 14px;
  border-radius: 8px;
  text-decoration: none;
  font-weight: 600;
  border: 1px solid rgba(11,92,255,0.12);
  color: var(--accent);
  background: transparent;
}
.btn-primary {
  background: var(--accent);
  color: #fff;
  border: none;
}

/* ---------- Responsive tweak ---------- */
@media (max-width: 520px) {
  .profile-card { padding: 18px; }
  .avatar { width: 110px; height: 110px; margin-top: -60px; }
  .name { font-size: 1.25rem; }
}

Plain-language explanation (CSS):

  • :root stores variables (colors, radius) so changing theme is one-line work later.

  • * { box-sizing: border-box } makes width/height include padding & border — very important so sizing behaves as you expect. (See MDN box model.) MDN Web Docs

  • The .profile-card rule makes a centered white card with shadow and rounded corners. max-width keeps it from getting too wide on large screens.

  • .avatar uses object-fit: cover so the image fills the circle without squishing (useful when images have different proportions).

  • .skills uses flexbox (display:flex) so items lay out in a row and wrap when space is tight. Flexbox is the right tool for one-dimensional alignment. See MDN Flexbox guide for details. MDN Web Docs

  • Media query @media (max-width:520px) adjusts sizes on phones.

Work in this order (don’t skip steps — this trains mental models):

  1. Step 1 — HTML skeleton (we already did): understand each tag — why main, section, h1, p, ul, li, img.

    • Practice: explain aloud what each tag does.

  2. Step 2 — Add avatar: put an image in images/avatar.jpg. If it doesn’t show, open the browser console (F12) and look at the Network tab — you’ll see a 404 if the path is wrong. Fix the filename or path.

  3. Step 3 — Add skills list: it's a ul of li elements. Use class="skill" on each li so you can style them later.

  4. Step 4 — Add basic CSS: paste styles.css. Save & refresh. Notice spacing, shadow, rounded corners — these are padding, box-shadow, border-radius.

  5. Step 5 — Box model test: open DevTools (F12), select the .profile-card element, and inspect the box model (padding, border, margin). Try changing padding live in DevTools to see how it affects layout. (This visually cements box model understanding.) MDN Web Docs

  6. Step 6 — Flexbox for skills: watch how .skills switches from a single row to wrapped lines when you resize. In DevTools, toggle display:flex off/on to see the difference. Read MDN Flexbox quick guide as you experiment. MDN Web Docs

  7. Step 7 — Responsive check: shrink the browser width — does the avatar and text stay readable? If not, tweak the media query.

  8. Step 8 — Accessibility: make sure alt is helpful and a links have meaningful text. For example use alt="Portrait of Your Name wearing a blue shirt".

Quick debugging tips (you’ll use these now and forever)

🌍 The CSS Breakdown

Here’s a typical CSS file you may have seen for the profile page:

css
body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  background-color: #f4f4f4;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

.container {
  width: 80%;
  max-width: 900px;
  margin: 20px auto;
  background: white;
  padding: 20px;
  border-radius: 8px;
  box-shadow: 0px 0px 10px rgba(0,0,0,0.1);
}

h1 {
  text-align: center;
  color: #333;
}

img {
  display: block;
  margin: 0 auto;
  border-radius: 50%;
  width: 150px;
  height: 150px;
}

p {
  line-height: 1.6;
  color: #555;
}

ul {
  list-style-type: square;
  padding-left: 20px;
}

a {
  color: blue;
  text-decoration: none;
}

a:hover {
  text-decoration: underline;
}

🟢 Step 1: body { ... }

css
body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  background-color: #f4f4f4;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

  • font-family: Arial, sans-serif; → Sets all text to use the Arial font. If Arial isn’t available, it uses a similar sans-serif font.

  • background-color: #f4f4f4; → Gives the page a light gray background.

  • margin: 0; → Removes default white space around the page.

  • padding: 0; → Removes default spacing inside the body.

👉 This is like resetting the page and choosing fonts & background.

🟢 Step 2: .container { ... }

css
.container {
  width: 80%;
  max-width: 900px;
  margin: 20px auto;
  background: white;
  padding: 20px;
  border-radius: 8px;
  box-shadow: 0px 0px 10px rgba(0,0,0,0.1);
}

  • width: 80%; → The box takes 80% of the screen width.

  • max-width: 900px; → But it won’t go wider than 900px, even on a big screen.

  • margin: 20px auto; → Adds 20px space on top & bottom, and auto centers it horizontally.

  • background: white; → The box background is white (to stand out from gray page).

  • padding: 20px; → Adds space inside the box so text isn’t stuck to the edge.

  • border-radius: 8px; → Rounds the corners of the box slightly.

  • box-shadow: 0px 0px 10px rgba(0,0,0,0.1); → Adds a soft shadow to make it pop off the page.

👉 This creates the profile card effect.

🟢 Step 3: h1 { ... }

css
h1 {
  text-align: center;
  color: #333;
}

  • text-align: center; → Centers your name/title.

  • color: #333; → Dark gray text color (softer than pure black).

🟢 Step 4: img { ... }

css
img {
  display: block;
  margin: 0 auto;
  border-radius: 50%;
  width: 150px;
  height: 150px;
}

  • display: block; → Makes the image behave like a block element.

  • margin: 0 auto; → Centers the image horizontally.

  • border-radius: 50%; → Cuts the corners evenly to make it a perfect circle.

  • width: 150px; height: 150px; → Resizes the image to a fixed size.

👉 That’s how your profile picture became round and centered.

🟢 Step 5: p { ... }

css
p {
  line-height: 1.6;
  color: #555;
}

  • line-height: 1.6; → Adds more space between lines, making paragraphs easier to read.

  • color: #555; → Medium gray text (again, softer than black).

🟢 Step 6: ul { ... }

css
ul {
  list-style-type: square;
  padding-left: 20px;
}

  • list-style-type: square; → Changes bullet points to squares instead of circles.

  • padding-left: 20px; → Moves the list a little inward so bullets don’t touch the edge.

🟢 Step 7: a { ... } and a:hover { ... }

css
a {
  color: blue;
  text-decoration: none;
}

a:hover {
  text-decoration: underline;
}

  • color: blue; → Makes all links blue.

  • text-decoration: none; → Removes the underline (by default, links are underlined).

  • a:hover { text-decoration: underline; } → When you hover your mouse over the link, the underline comes back (for interactivity).

🔑 How to Never Forget

👉 Here’s the mental shortcut:

  • body → general look of the whole page (font, background, reset margins).

  • .container → the main box for your content.

  • h1, p, ul, img, a → how each element should look inside the box.

  • hover → effects when you interact.

  3. Try list-style-type: circle; instead of square.

  4. Make your links red, but on hover turn them green.

This way you’ll play with the rules and they’ll stick in your memory forever.

⚠️ Why you may not see much difference

  • If you didn’t link the CSS file properly in your HTML (common beginner mistake).
    Your HTML <head> should have:

    html
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">

    (assuming your CSS file is named style.css and is in the same folder).

  • If the browser cached the old version, it may look unchanged. Always press CTRL + SHIFT + R (Windows) or CMD + SHIFT + R (Mac) to reload without cache.

  • Some styles are subtle. For example:

    • The box-shadow is very light (rgba(0,0,0,0.1)), so on certain monitors it’s barely visible.

    • The background #f4f4f4 looks almost white unless compared side by side with pure white.

👉 To test if your CSS is working, try making an obvious change:

css
body {
  background-color: lightblue;
}

If the page turns blue, then your CSS is linked and working. If it doesn’t → the CSS isn’t connected to the HTML yet.

ChatGPT said:

Nice 👏👏 this HTML file is clean and very well-structured — you did a great job!

Let’s break it down step by step so you really understand what each part does and why it’s there.

🟢 Step 1: The Head

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" />
  <title>My Profile — Day 5</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" />
</head>

  • <!DOCTYPE html> → tells the browser this is HTML5.

  • <html lang="en"> → starts the document, sets language to English.

  • <meta charset="utf-8" /> → makes sure special characters (like emojis, accents) display correctly.

  • <meta name="viewport" ...> → ensures the page scales well on phones/tablets (responsive design).

  • <title> → title shown in the browser tab.

  • <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" /> → connects your HTML to the CSS file.

👉 Without this link, your CSS won’t apply.

🟢 Step 2: The Body Wrapper

html
<body>
  <main class="profile-page">

  • <body> → where all visible content goes.

  • <main> → semantic tag that marks the main content of your page.

  • class="profile-page" → lets you style the main wrapper in CSS.

🟢 Step 3: The Profile Card

html
<section id="profile-card" class="profile-card">

  • <section> → groups related content together.

  • id="profile-card" → unique identifier (useful if you want to jump-link to this section).

  • class="profile-card" → lets you apply CSS styling to this section.

🟢 Step 4: The Image

html
<img class="avatar" src="img/Icognito.jpeg" alt="Icognito Avatar"/>

  • <img> → displays an image.

  • class="avatar" → will style the image (like making it round).

  • src="img/Icognito.jpeg" → path to the picture file (must be inside an img folder).

  • alt="Icognito Avatar" → text shown if the image doesn’t load (important for accessibility & SEO).

🟢 Step 5: The Name, Role, and Bio

html
<h1 class="name">Charles</h1>
<p class="role">Aspiring Web Developer</p>
<p class="bio">I build small web projects ...</p>

  • <h1> → main heading (your name).

  • <p> → paragraphs for role and bio.

  • Each has its own class so you can style them separately (.name, .role, .bio).

🟢 Step 6: The Skills

html
<h2 class="section-title">Skills</h2>
<ul class="skills">
  <li class="skill">HTML</li>
  <li class="skill">CSS</li>
  <li class="skill">JavaScript</li>
</ul>

  • <h2> → sub-heading (section title).

  • <ul> → unordered list (bullets).

  • <li> → list items (each skill).

  • Classes let you style the title, list, and items differently.

🟢 Step 7: The Action Buttons

html
<div class="actions">
  <a class="btn" href="https://www.facebook.com/..." target="_blank" rel="noopener">Facebook</a>
  <a class="btn" href="https://www.youtube.com/..." target="_blank" rel="noopener">Youtube</a>
  <a class="btn btn-primary" href="#" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GitHub</a>
</div>

  • <div> → groups the action links.

  • <a> → anchor tag (link).

  • class="btn" → makes it look like a button.

  • btn-primary → special style (maybe a highlighted button).

  • target="_blank" → opens link in new tab.

  • rel="noopener" → security measure when opening new tabs.

🟢 Step 8: Closing Tags

html
</section>
</main>
</body>
</html>

Closes all open elements in order.

🔎 Step-by-Step Breakdown (easy to remember)

1. Reset

css
* { margin: 0; padding: 0; box-sizing: border-box; }

  • Removes browser’s default spacing.

  • box-sizing: border-box makes widths easier to control.

2. Body

css
body { font-family: Arial; background: #f0f2f5; color: #333; line-height: 1.6; }

  • Sets font, background color, and text color.

  • line-height = space between lines of text.

3. Container

css
.container { max-width: 900px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 20px; }

  • Prevents page from stretching too wide.

  • Centers everything horizontally.

  • Adds padding around edges.

4. Profile Page Layout

css
.profile-page { display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; min-height: 100vh; }

  • Uses Flexbox to center the card in the middle of the screen.

  • 100vh = full screen height.

5. Profile Card

css
.profile-card { background: white; padding: 30px; border-radius: 12px; box-shadow: ...; text-align: center; }

  • White card with rounded corners and a shadow.

  • text-align: center makes text and image centered.

6. Avatar

css
.avatar { width: 120px; height: 120px; border-radius: 50%; object-fit: cover; }

  • Forces the picture to be round.

  • object-fit: cover crops the image nicely inside the circle.

7. Text (Name, Role, Bio)

  • .name → Big, bold text.

  • .role → Smaller, gray text.

  • .bio → Normal text, slightly gray.

8. Skills Section

css
.skills { list-style: none; display: flex; justify-content: center; gap: 10px; }
.skill { background: #eee; padding: 6px 12px; border-radius: 20px; }

  • Turns the list into nice “pills” (rounded skill tags).

  • Uses Flexbox to arrange them side by side.

9. Buttons

css
.btn { border: 1px solid #333; padding: 8px 15px; border-radius: 6px; transition: 0.3s; }
.btn:hover { background: #333; color: #fff; }
.btn-primary { background: blue; color: white; }
.btn-primary:hover { background: darkblue; }

  • Normal .btn = bordered button with hover effect.

  • .btn-primary = special blue button.

You said:
Is it possible to build a profile page on an already written html document?
ChatGPT said:

Yes ✅ it’s very possible.

Think of it this way: your HTML document is like the skeleton (structure), and the profile page is just one “section” of that skeleton. You don’t always have to start fresh — you can insert the profile page inside your existing file.

🔎 How to do it

  1. Open your existing .html file.

  2. Inside the <body> ... </body>, add your profile page code. For example:

html
<body>
  <!-- Other parts of your page go here -->

  <!-- Profile Page Section -->
  <main class="profile-page">
    <section class="profile-card">
      <img class="avatar" src="img/Icognito.jpeg" alt="My Avatar">
      <h1 class="name">Charles</h1>
      <p class="role">Aspiring Web Developer</p>
      <p class="bio">I build small web projects to practice HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.</p>

      <h2 class="section-title">Skills</h2>
      <ul class="skills">
        <li class="skill">HTML</li>
        <li class="skill">CSS</li>
        <li class="skill">JavaScript</li>
      </ul>

      <div class="actions">
        <a class="btn" href="#">Facebook</a>
        <a class="btn" href="#">YouTube</a>
        <a class="btn btn-primary" href="#">GitHub</a>
      </div>
    </section>
  </main>

  <!-- Other parts of your page go here -->
</body>

  1. Make sure you link the styles.css file in your <head> (or add the CSS into a <style> block).

html
<head>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>

🔧 Things to keep in mind

  • If your page already has a <div class="container">, you can put the profile page inside that container so it stays aligned with your other content.

  • You can rename classes (like profile-card) if they clash with styles already written in your CSS.

  • The profile page will not “overwrite” your existing HTML, it will just add itself as another section.

Perfect 🎉 let’s add a little JavaScript spice to your profile page so you see how it works.

We’ll keep it very simple — when you click the GitHub button, a message will pop up.

1️⃣ Update your HTML

Inside your profile card, make sure the GitHub button has an id (so we can select it in JS):

html
<a id="github-btn" class="btn btn-primary" href="#" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GitHub</a>

2️⃣ Add JavaScript before the </body> tag

At the very bottom of your HTML (just before </body>), add a <script> tag:

html
<script>
  // Select the GitHub button
  const githubButton = document.getElementById('github-btn');

  // Add a click event
  githubButton.addEventListener('click', function(event) {
    event.preventDefault(); // stops the link from opening immediately
    alert('Welcome to my GitHub profile! 🚀');
  });
</script>

🔎 Explanation

  • document.getElementById('github-btn') → finds the button using its id.

  • .addEventListener('click', function(){...}) → listens for a click.

  • event.preventDefault() → stops the link from jumping to # immediately.

  • alert('...') → shows a popup message.

✅ Now when you click the GitHub button, you’ll see a popup message first. If you want, you can remove event.preventDefault(); and the popup will show and then the link will open.

Day 6 — Forms: form, input, label, button

Total time: ~2.5–3 hours

1) Watch & read (25–35 minutes) — watch only the exact sections I list

(These videos explain everything used in the build — structure, each input type, label usage and accessibility.)

    • 12:30–18:30 — <textarea>, <select>, placeholder, required.

    • 18:30–25:00 — submit behavior and simple client validation.
      (Good full tutorial that covers every form element and why to use them). YouTube

  2. MDN — “Your first form” (read): short, authoritative, accessibility-minded explanation of form structure and examples. Use this as your reference while building. developer.mozilla.org

  3. MDN — The <label> element (read): explains explicit for vs implicit nesting and why labels are essential for accessibility. Read the examples. developer.mozilla.org

  4. MDN — <input> reference (skim): great reference for input attributes (type, name, id, value, required, placeholder). developer.mozilla.org

Watching + reading time: ~25–35 min
(If you already know HTML tags — skim; otherwise follow the timestamps precisely.)

  • uses well-formed <label> + <input> combos (accessible),

  • uses id and name attributes so data would work when submitted,

4) Exact HTML — copy/paste into your profile page (recommended: place inside the container, below the profile card)

Add this chunk (either inside the same index.html below your section#profile-card or in a new file):

html
<!-- Contact section (place inside .container or below the profile card) -->
<section id="contact" class="contact-section">
  <h2>Contact Me</h2>
  <p>If you'd like to reach out, fill the form below and I'll get back to you.</p>

  <form id="contactForm" class="contact-form" novalidate>
    <!-- Name (text) -->
    <div class="form-row">
      <label for="name">Full name</label>
      <input id="name" name="name" type="text" placeholder="Your full name" required>
    </div>

    <!-- Email (email type validates basic email format) -->
    <div class="form-row">
      <label for="email">Email address</label>
      <input id="email" name="email" type="email" placeholder="you@example.com" required>
    </div>

    <!-- Reason (select dropdown) -->
    <div class="form-row">
      <label for="reason">Reason</label>
      <select id="reason" name="reason" required>
        <option value="">Select a reason</option>
        <option value="project">Project enquiry</option>
        <option value="job">Job opportunity</option>
        <option value="hello">Just saying hi</option>
      </select>
    </div>

    <!-- Message (textarea) -->
    <div class="form-row">
      <label for="message">Message</label>
      <textarea id="message" name="message" rows="5" placeholder="Write your message..." required></textarea>
    </div>

    <!-- Subscribe checkbox (optional) -->
    <div class="form-row form-row-inline">
      <label>
        <input type="checkbox" id="subscribe" name="subscribe"> Subscribe to updates
      </label>
    </div>

    <!-- Submit button -->
    <div class="form-row">
      <button type="submit" class="btn btn-primary">Send message</button>
      <button type="reset" class="btn">Reset</button>
    </div>

    <!-- Inline success message (hidden until submit) -->
    <div id="formMessage" class="form-message" aria-live="polite" style="display:none"></div>
  </form>
</section>

Explanation of important bits (so you never forget)

  • <form>: container for inputs; novalidate in the example disables browser automatic validation so the JS demo handles showing a nicer message — you can remove novalidate to let browser do default checks. See MDN. developer.mozilla.org

  • label for="id" pairs the label to the input with that id — clicking the label focuses the input and helps screen readers. You can also nest <input> inside <label> instead. developer.mozilla.org

  • input type="email" tells browsers to validate basic email format & show email keyboard on phones. See MDN for input types. developer.mozilla.org

  • name attribute matters for form submission — servers expect name=value pairs. Always include name. (W3Schools/MDN explain this.) w3schools.com+1

Why this looks professional:

6) Tiny JavaScript: validate & show success (paste before </body>)

html
<script>
  const form = document.getElementById('contactForm');
  const formMessage = document.getElementById('formMessage');

  form.addEventListener('submit', function(e) {
    e.preventDefault(); // stop default submission for demo

    // clear previous styles/messages
    formMessage.style.display = 'none';
    formMessage.textContent = '';
    const inputs = form.querySelectorAll('input, textarea, select');
    inputs.forEach(i => i.classList.remove('form-error'));

    // basic validation
    const name = form.name.value.trim();
    const email = form.email.value.trim();
    const reason = form.reason.value;
    const message = form.message.value.trim();

    let hasError = false;
    if (!name) {
      form.name.classList.add('form-error');
      hasError = true;
    }
    // quick email regex (simple) — just to demonstrate
    const emailRe = /^[^\s@]+@[^\s@]+\.[^\s@]+$/;
    if (!email || !emailRe.test(email)) {
      form.email.classList.add('form-error');
      hasError = true;
    }
    if (!reason) {
      form.reason.classList.add('form-error');
      hasError = true;
    }
    if (!message) {
      form.message.classList.add('form-error');
      hasError = true;
    }

    if (hasError) {
      formMessage.style.display = 'block';
      formMessage.textContent = 'Please fix the red fields and try again.';
      formMessage.style.background = '#fff5f5';
      formMessage.style.border = '1px solid #fecaca';
      return;
    }

    // success — show a friendly message and clear values
    formMessage.style.display = 'block';
    formMessage.textContent = 'Thanks! Your message was sent (demo). I will reply soon.';
    formMessage.style.background = '#ecfdf5';
    formMessage.style.border = '1px solid #bbf7d0';

    // reset the form (optional)
    form.reset();

    // optionally log the submitted data to console (for practice)
    console.log({ name, email, reason, message, subscribe: form.subscribe.checked });
  });
</script>

Notes:

  • This JS prevents the real submit (because you don't yet have a server). It validates required fields, highlights errors and shows a success message.

  • When you later have a backend, remove e.preventDefault() and set <form action="https://yourserver/endpoint" method="post"> so data is sent to the server.

8) Accessibility & best practices (readable checklist)

  • Always include <label> associated with each input (use for + id OR wrap input inside label). developer.mozilla.org

  • Use type="email" for email inputs (phones show email keyboard). developer.mozilla.org

  • Add required when input must be filled (also helps built-in browser validation). developer.mozilla.org

  • Use aria-live="polite" on messages so screen readers announce success/errors.

  • Keep name attributes — servers expect them.

9) Debugging tips (fast)

  • If the JS “doesn’t run”, check the browser console for errors.

  • If CSS not applied, check <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css"> path and clear cache (Ctrl+Shift+R).

  • If inputs aren’t focusing when clicking labels, confirm for value matches id. developer.mozilla.org

10) Quick reference / docs (the most important short list)

  • MDN — Your first form. developer.mozilla.org

  • MDN — <label> element. developer.mozilla.org

  • MDN — <input> reference. developer.mozilla.org

  • W3Schools — HTML forms (simple cheatsheet). w3schools.com

  • Video — Learn HTML Forms In 25 Minutes (best single tutorial). YouTube

Final checklist — you can explain all of these at the end:

  • What <form> does and why method/action matter. developer.mozilla.org

  • How to associate <label> with <input> and why that matters for accessibility. developer.mozilla.org

  • Key input types (text, email, password, checkbox, radio, file, submit) and textarea vs input. developer.mozilla.org

  • How name, id, and class differ and when to use each. w3schools.com

  • How to style form fields for a neat professional look and how to test responsiveness.

🎨 CSS (save as styles.css)

css
/* General Styles */
body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  background: #f4f6f9;
  color: #333;
}

.container {
  max-width: 900px;
  margin: 20px auto;
  padding: 20px;
}

/* Profile Card */
.profile-card {
  text-align: center;
  background: #fff;
  padding: 30px;
  border-radius: 15px;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 10px rgba(0,0,0,0.1);
  margin-bottom: 40px;
}

.avatar {
  width: 120px;
  height: 120px;
  border-radius: 50%;
  margin-bottom: 15px;
}

.name {
  font-size: 28px;
  margin: 10px 0;
}

.role {
  font-size: 18px;
  color: #555;
}

.bio {
  font-size: 16px;
  margin: 15px 0;
  color: #666;
}

.section-title {
  font-size: 20px;
  margin: 20px 0 10px;
}

.skills {
  list-style: none;
  padding: 0;
  margin: 0 0 20px;
}

.skill {
  display: inline-block;
  background: #eaeaea;
  margin: 5px;
  padding: 8px 12px;
  border-radius: 5px;
  font-size: 14px;
}

/* Buttons */
.btn {
  display: inline-block;
  text-decoration: none;
  background: #ddd;
  color: #333;
  padding: 10px 15px;
  border-radius: 8px;
  margin: 5px;
  transition: background 0.3s;
}

.btn:hover {
  background: #bbb;
}

.btn-primary {
  background: #333;
  color: #fff;
}

.btn-primary:hover {
  background: #555;
}

/* Contact Form */
.contact-section {
  background: #fff;
  padding: 30px;
  border-radius: 15px;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 10px rgba(0,0,0,0.1);
}

.contact-form {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
}

.form-group {
  margin-bottom: 15px;
}

label {
  margin-bottom: 5px;
  display: block;
  font-weight: bold;
}

input, textarea {
  width: 100%;
  padding: 10px;
  border: 1px solid #ccc;
  border-radius: 6px;
  font-size: 14px;
}

input:focus, textarea:focus {
  border-color: #333;
  outline: none;
}

button {
  align-self: flex-start;
}

📝 Day 1–7 Practice Checklist (Offline Exercises)

✅ Day 1: Headings, Paragraphs, Links

  1. Open VS Code → create a file day1.html.

  2. Write <!DOCTYPE html> and set up basic HTML structure.

  3. Add:

    • One <h1> for your name.

    • Two <p> paragraphs about yourself.

    • One <a> link to your Facebook or YouTube profile (target="_blank").

  4. Save → open in browser.
    👉 Key: Learn how <h1>–<h6>, <p>, and <a> work.

✅ Day 2: Images & Lists

  1. Create a file day2.html.

  2. Add an <img> of your choice (local or online).

    • Use alt text.

    • Set width="200".

  3. Add an unordered list (<ul>) of 3 hobbies.

  4. Add an ordered list (<ol>) of your 3 goals.

  5. Save → check how lists and images display.
    👉 Key: Practice <img>, <ul>, <ol>, <li>.

✅ Day 3: Divs & Spans

  1. Create day3.html.

  2. Wrap your Day 2 content inside a <div class="container">.

  3. Add a <span> around a single word inside a paragraph and give it a different color using CSS.
    👉 Example:

html
<p>I love <span class="highlight">coding</span> every day.</p>

👉 Key: Divs = structure, Spans = inline styling.

✅ Day 4: Attributes (id, class, href, src, alt)

  1. Create day4.html.

  2. Add:

    • An <img> with id="profile-pic".

    • A <p class="intro">This is me learning HTML.</p>

    • A link <a href="https://www.google.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Google</a>.
      👉 Key: id = unique, class = reusable, href/src/alt = essential.

✅ Day 5: Profile Page

  1. Create index.html and styles.css.

  2. Add:

    • Profile picture (<img>).

    • Name (<h1>).

    • Short bio (<p>).

    • Skills list (<ul>).

  3. Style with CSS (background, borders, spacing).
    👉 Key: Combine all previous knowledge into one neat card.

✅ Day 6: Forms (Inputs, Labels, Buttons)

  1. Create day6.html.

  2. Add a form with:

    • Name (text input).

    • Email (email input).

    • Message (textarea).

    • Submit button.

  3. Style inputs with CSS: padding, border-radius, hover effect.
    👉 Key: Learn form structure and how labels connect with inputs.

✅ Day 7: Contact Form Project (Integrated)

  1. Open index.html (Profile Page).

  2. Add a new <section id="contact">.

  3. Inside, create a Contact Form (Name, Email, Message, Button).

  4. Wrap each input in a <div class="form-group">.

  5. Style with CSS (max-width, centered form, box shadow).

  6. Add tiny JS for interactivity:

html
<script>
  const githubButton = document.getElementById('github-btn');

    event.preventDefault();
    alert('🚀 Welcome to my GitHub profile!');
  });

Let’s keep this clean and beginner-friendly.
Here’s the HTML only for your Day 7 Contact Form Project (no CSS, so you can practice styling yourself):

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Contact Me</title>
</head>
<body>

  <!-- Page Heading -->
  <h1>Contact Me</h1>
  <p>If you have any questions, feel free to send me a message using the form below.</p>

  <!-- Contact Form -->
  <form action="#" method="post">

    <!-- Full Name -->
    <label for="name">Full Name:</label><br>
    <input type="text" id="name" name="name" placeholder="Enter your full name" required><br><br>

    <!-- Email Address -->
    <label for="email">Email:</label><br>
    <input type="email" id="email" name="email" placeholder="Enter your email" required><br><br>

    <!-- Message -->
    <label for="message">Message:</label><br>
    <textarea id="message" name="message" rows="5" placeholder="Write your message here..." required></textarea><br><br>

    <!-- Submit Button -->
    <button type="submit">Send Message</button>

  </form>

  <!-- Extra Contact Info (List & Links for practice from earlier days) -->
  <h2>Other Ways to Reach Me</h2>
  <ul>
    <li>Email: yourname@example.com</li>
    <li><a href="https://facebook.com" target="_blank">Facebook</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://youtube.com" target="_blank">YouTube</a></li>
  </ul>

</body>
</html>

What this HTML teaches you:

  • <form> = the container for the form.

  • <label> = text describing an input.

  • <input> = text/email fields.

  • <textarea> = bigger box for messages.

  • <button> = submits the form.

  • Extra list + links → review from Day 1–6.

⚡ Your next move:

  1. Watch the video I gave you.

  2. Try this HTML in VS Code → open in your browser.

  3. Then use CSS yourself to style it neat & professional (padding, margins, background, hover effect on button).

Day 7 — CSS Styles

css
/* Reset default browser spacing */
* {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif; /* clean readable font */
}

/* Page background and overall layout */
body {
  background-color: #f9f9f9;   /* light gray background */
  color: #333;                 /* dark gray text */
  line-height: 1.6;
  padding: 20px;
}

/* Headings */
h1, h2 {
  text-align: center;          /* center main headings */
  margin-bottom: 15px;
  color: #222;                 /* slightly darker heading text */
}

/* Paragraphs */
p {
  margin-bottom: 15px;
  text-align: center;          /* center intro text */
}

/* Contact Form */
form {
  background: #fff;            /* white form background */
  max-width: 500px;            /* limit form width */
  margin: 20px auto;           /* center horizontally */
  padding: 20px;
  border-radius: 10px;         /* rounded corners */
  box-shadow: 0 0 10px rgba(0,0,0,0.1); /* light shadow */
}

/* Labels */
label {
  display: block;              /* put label above input */
  margin-bottom: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
}

/* Inputs & textarea */
input, textarea {
  width: 100%;                 /* take full width */
  padding: 10px;
  margin-bottom: 15px;
  border: 1px solid #ccc;      /* light border */
  border-radius: 5px;
  font-size: 14px;
}

/* Focus effect for inputs */
input:focus, textarea:focus {
  border-color: #007BFF;       /* blue border when active */
  outline: none;
}

/* Button */
button {
  background: #007BFF;         /* blue background */
  color: white;                /* white text */
  border: none;
  padding: 12px;
  border-radius: 5px;
  cursor: pointer;
  font-size: 16px;
  width: 100%;
}

/* Button hover effect */
button:hover {
  background: #0056b3;         /* darker blue on hover */
}

/* Skills list */
ul {
  max-width: 400px;
  margin: 20px auto;
  list-style: square inside;   /* bullet points inside */
}

li {
  margin-bottom: 8px;
}

/* Table */
table {
  border-collapse: collapse;
  margin: 20px auto;
  width: 60%;
  background: #fff;
  box-shadow: 0 0 5px rgba(0,0,0,0.1);
}

th, td {
  padding: 10px;
  border: 1px solid #ccc;
  text-align: center;
}

/* Links */
a {
  text-decoration: none;
  color: #007BFF;
  margin: 0 5px;
}

a:hover {
  text-decoration: underline;
}

🔑 How to Understand This CSS

  • * { ... } → Resets spacing so all browsers look the same.

  • body { ... } → Sets background, text color, padding.

  • form { ... } → Creates a card-like box for the form (centered, white, shadow).

  • label { ... } → Makes labels appear above inputs.

  • input, textarea { ... } → Styles all fields the same (width 100%, padding).

  • button { ... } → Turns plain button into a big blue modern button.

  • ul, li → Styles your skills/hobbies lists neatly.

  • table { ... } → Styles availability table (border + centered).

  • a { ... } → Styles links with blue color and hover underline.

👉 This CSS will give your Day 7 project a professional look without being too advanced.

🏗️ Step-by-Step Build Guide

1. Build a Table (HTML)

Create file day8-9.html with a table in the body:

html
<section id="data">
  <h2>Project Status</h2>
  <table>
    <tr>
      <th>Project</th><th>Status</th><th>Completion</th>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>Portfolio</td><td>Done</td><td>100%</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>Blog</td><td>In Progress</td><td>60%</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>Contact Form</td><td>Completed</td><td>100%</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
</section>

Try adding a row with colspan:

html
<tr>
  <td colspan="3">All projects updated recently</td>
</tr>

2. Add Page Layout (HTML)

Wrap your content in semantic tags:

html
<header>
  <h1>My Website</h1>
  <nav>
    <a href="#data">Projects</a>
    <a href="#contact">Contact</a>
  </nav>
</header>

<main>
  <!-- your <section id="data"> table goes here -->
</main>

<footer>
  <p>&copy; 2025 My Name</p>
</footer>

Then below or above table, place your contact form (from Day 7) inside <main> or another <section id="contact">.

3. CSS Styling (basic)

In styles.css, add:

css
header, footer {
  background: #333;
  color: white;
  padding: 15px;
  text-align: center;
}

nav a {
  color: white;
  text-decoration: none;
  margin: 0 10px;
}

main {
  padding: 20px;
}

table {
  width: 100%;
  border-collapse: collapse;
  margin-top: 20px;
}
th, td {
  border: 1px solid #ccc;
  padding: 10px;
  text-align: center;
}
th {
  background: #444;
  color: white;
}
tr:nth-child(even) {
  background: #f2f2f2;
}
footer {
  margin-top: 30px;
}

  • How to build and structure HTML tables (<table>, <tr>, <th>, <td>, colspan)

  • Why and how to use semantic HTML tags: <header>, <nav>, <main>, <section>, <footer>

  • How to style a table (borders, row striping, header shading)

  • How to integrate everything you’ve done (forms, profile, lists, layout) into one coherent page

🎨 Simple CSS (for clarity)

css
body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  line-height: 1.6;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

header, footer {
  background: #333;
  color: #fff;
  padding: 15px;
  text-align: center;
}

nav a {
  color: #fff;
  margin: 0 10px;
  text-decoration: none;
}

main {
  display: flex;
  padding: 20px;
  gap: 20px;
}

section {
  flex: 3;
}

aside {
  flex: 1;
  background: #f4f4f4;
  padding: 15px;
}

article {
  border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc;
  margin-bottom: 15px;
  padding-bottom: 10px;
}

✅ What You’ll Learn

  • Difference between <section> vs <article> vs <div>.

  • Correct placement of <header>, <footer>, <aside>.

  • How to combine all previous knowledge (links, lists, forms, tables) inside a semantic layout.
